contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox Paris metro |pic= |Name=Ranelagh |Day=8 November |Year=1922 |Access= |Municipality=the 16th arrondissement of Paris |Zone=1 |Next= {{Paris Metro/next|9|Jasmin|La Muette}} | X=51 | Y=84 }} '''Ranelagh''' is a [[metro station|station]] of the [[Paris Métro]] on the ''Rue de Ranelagh''. The station opened on 8 November 1922 with the opening of the first section of the line from [[Trocadéro (Paris Métro)|Trocadéro]] to [[Exelmans (Paris Métro)|Exelmans]]. The street of ''Rue de Ranelagh'' was named after [[Baron Ranelagh|Lord Ranelagh]], an Irish peer and amateur at music, who built a rotunda for concerts in the park of his property in [[Chelsea, London|Chelsea]] in 1750. A similar establishment was established on the grounds of the [[Château de la Muette]] in 1774. The place was fashionable under [[Marie Antoinette]], under the [[French Directory|Directory]] and then again under the [[Bourbon Restoration|Restoration]]. It disappeared in 1858 with the creation of the [[Bois de Boulogne]]. {{Paris Metro/line 9}} {{coord|48.85502|N|2.269634|E|region:FR_type:landmark_scale:2000_source:frwiki|display=title|format=dms}} [[Category:Railway stations opened in 1922]]
